item.description:
"RPG-like card game for 2 players, based on [Lloyd] Krasner's Superhero Slugfest Card Combat rules."

"Each player gets one deck. A deck represents a party of adventurers, all its members, and all of their special abilities. A party has 6 Members. A deck has 60 cards."

"Each hero is represented by 10 cards: Five of these are Character cards. The five character cards have a Force value and the name of the hero. The other five are Ability cards. The five ability cards have a Force modifier and the name of the hero which belongs to."

The players fight a series of battles through card play. To win the game you must kill or wound all 10 of your opponent's heroes.

This free, online rules set describes the components that you will need to create in order to play. Rules and print-and-play components are available on the Yahoo group Fermwarp.

Taken from the official website:

Golf Board Game: GolfEgo™
...... a great way to play the game

GolfEgo is fun! It's easy to understand and play, whether you're a regular golfer or not.

Now everyone can play a round of golf, young and old and right at home. And just as exciting as the real game!

GolfEgo™ is an innovative board game based on golf. Like when you are playing outside on the green, this board game is a challenge to your Ego. Play 9, 18 or just a few holes. Create your own rules, or play one of the available games like stroke play, match play, skins or fun golf, a kind of Ludo...

The 4 pawns represent the players and have been designed just for this game, and so are the 4 dices which are the virtual clubs in your bag. So with GolfEgo™ you can decide which one to use. Playing safe or taking a risk, just like the real thing!

The game itself:
Much attention has been given to detail. Inside the colourful box there is a nicely designed board which covers 18 holes (9 holes each side). The board features ponds, bunkers and greens. It even has a clubhouse! Of course the box is delivered to you with dices, pawns and a notebook for writing down the scores.

Old Janx Spirit is a Decktet rummy game for 2 players.
Each player is dealt a hand of ten cards,the remaining cards become the draw pile.
On each turn draw one card and discard one card.
When all ten cards are part of melds the round ends and you score one point.

Link to wiki article: http://wiki.decktet.com/game:old-janx-spirit

item.description: It's the "Yahtzee Hands Down" Card Game! Keep your wits about you and your eye on the cards! Collect dice cards to make classic combinations - 3 of a kind, 4 of a kind, small straight, full house and YAHTZEE! Re-roll by discarding cards you don't need and taking a chance on new ones! But here's the twist... pit your hand against another player's. Score high and win the Combo card points! Great Yahtzee fun in a card game!

item.description: This game is played with a 32-card pack ranking AKQJ10987. A trick always consists of four card in four different suit, hence players have to play a card in a different suit or pass, and then one player can add more cards in the same trick. Tricks score for certain combinations, the first partnership to reach 100 points wins.

A Swedish game where you move a traffic sign around a board, face traffic-based events and answer related questions. No one is very sure why traffic signs would need to know about these things. It's not a Monopoly clone but shares some minor visual elements, presumably in order to ride on Monopoly's popularity.

NOTE: While traditionally credited as a Kärnan game it is more likely that the real publisher is moped and bicycle manufacturer Monark AB and that this is an advertising object. Please note how the persons and bikes are introduced on the box lid. (Kärnan is however the manufacturer of the game.) In the years between 1945 and around 1960 (when the automobile become common) the moped and bicycle markets in Sweden was heated with fierce competition between Monark, Nymans, Husqvarna and other manufacturers. Monark would eventually "win the race" and swallow the closest competitors, first Nymans and then in 1962 Husqvarna's divisions for bicycles, mopeds and boat engines.
Swedish educational trivia game about traffic rules with a "magic robot"-style device for revealing the correct answers.

Open up that Golden Gate! Its up to your wits, and a little bit of luck, to make the right plays and pile up the points.

Set down cards in number order. A yellow card means you take a chip out of the Golden Gate. Here’s where you show off your skills…can you place them at the right times to get the best chips? Or will the opportunity pass you by? And don’t get stuck with red cards, or you’ll lose chips.

It’s a fast, friendly showdown for the gold with the fine craftsmanship and colorful designs you’ve come to expect from Blue Orange Games.

item.description:
How quick and precise are your fingers? Find out as you build piggy piles in this thrilling stacking game.
 When two cards match, players race to construct a tower of piggies that is tops of the sty! Be careful! There are rules to how you can stack them. And your pile must stand up with the right number and color. Run out of cards and you are king of the pen.

Players will be on the edge of their seats and will take like pigs to mud as they shout "Pigzup!"

item.description:
PeekPoker is a fast-paced and fun dice version of its cousin, Texas Hold’em Poker.

Players use 3 dice hidden inside their see-through cup and 3 community dice to make their combinations.

Think you’ve got a good hand? Make a bet and get the chance to snag your opponents’ chips. And beware of bluffers... they’ll fill you with doubt!

Make a bet and get the chance to snag your opponents’ chips.

A 2 player game play on a 3 by 3 grid. Each player has 3 stones and the object is to get 3 stones in a row (not diagonal.) Once a player has placed his three stones he moves one of his stones on his turn.

There is a note that comes with the game that says this game was taught to the publisher by an Iraqi boy while he was serving in Iraq. They played this game in the sand with stones.

This was the "mini" release of LudodÃ©lire. It came with a non-mounted course of Monaco and shortened rules.

It differs from the "mini" version of Descartes Editeur (Formula DÃ© Mini) as well as from the new release of Asmodee (Formula D), which has the same name.

Formule Dé is a fast-paced racing game in which the cars' top speeds are limited by having to end a certain number of turns in each curve of the racetrack. This can be tricky, because although players can regulate their speeds by choosing which gear to be in and each gear allows a certain range of movement, the exact amount is determined randomly. Great fun for a big group.

The base game came with:

 a d20 dice
 Ten plastic cars (2 blue, 2 red, 2 white, 2 green, 2 yellow, one in each colour with a black heck spoiler)
 one circuits 1&2 (Monaco, Hockenheim or Silverstone)
 Rulebook
 Racing sheets
 Ten gear markers (2 blue, 2 red, 2 white, 2 green, 2 yellow)




This was the first release of a game of the family Formule Dé/Formula Dé/Formula D.

Formule Dé was released 1991 by LudodÃ©lire. In 1997, the second release Formula De came from Descartes Editeur. And the newest release from Asmodee came in 2008.

Ludodélire published 13 courses for Formule Dé, 1 World Championchip expansion and a mini Variant (called Formula D).

item.description:
This game is played with a standard deck of cards (including jokers and/or removing cards, depending on the number of players). 25 cards are put face-down on the table, forming a 5x5 square. A player in his turn takes any face-down card from the square, adds it to his hand, and fill the gap with any card from his hand face up.

When all the cards in the square are face up, the value of the square counted according to the Poker combinations in the rows and columns. Then each player chooses five cards from his hand; the player with the best Poker combination scores twice the value of the square, the player with the worst Poker combination scores the value of the square.

This game is played with a standard deck of cards. The game consists of three phases as follows:

1. Melds. In Phase 1 you both try to improve your hands by bidding for new cards from the stock. When none remain in stock, you score for any melds (card combinations) contained in your revised hands. This phase is rather like Gops.

2. Tricks. In Phase 2 you play out your revised hands to 13 tricks, aiming especially to win an odd number of tricks (1, 3, 5 etc). This phase is rather like Piquet.

3. Play-off. Finally, you each pick up as a new hand the 13 cards you used for bidding in the first phase, and aim to be the first to play out all the cards from your hand. This phase is rather like Arsehole / President / Trouduc.

This game is played with a standard deck of cards stripped down to AKQJT987 plus one Joker. Eleven tricks are played, hence one player will win either the middling number of tricks, or, if two win the same number, a unique number of tricks. That player is designated Hamlet. A new trump suit and a scoring multiplier (whether it is more desirable "to be or not to be" Hamlet) are decided at the start of each round.

More information can be found at http://www.davidparlett.co.uk/oricards/hamlet.html

WABA
The players try to connect opposing sides of the gameboard. There's a two player and a three player version. Two players each have 40 pieces, three players each have 30 pieces. 
The first move for each player is to place a piece on the startline. From that position a continuous line is to be formed. After the first move players may place a piece on every field on the board that is unoccupied by a piece of the adversaries.
When all pieces have been played and no line connecting the opposing sides of the board is formed, the game ends in a draw.

WABEN-HALMA
Waben-Halma is a two player game. Each has 15 pieces to be placed in the 'Waben-triangle' at the base of the board. The object is to be the first player to have moved all 15 pieces in the starttriangle of the opponent. The rules of this game are exactly like Halma.

DREIER-WABEN
This is a game for two or three players. Each players has 15 pieces. Every turn one piece is to be placed on the board. The object is to be the player who has formed the largest number of triangle formations on the board. Such triangle formations contain three pieces of the same colour in pyramid form.

WABEN-BILDER
Waben-Bilder is a game of shape building. Each player tries to form a certain figure (a flower, house, key etc.) on the board. The first to complete such a figure wins the game.

item.description: Dave Dawson was the lead character in a number of books, called "The War Adventure Series" written by Robert Sidney Brown from 1942 - 1946. A couple of those books were converted to board games. This is one of those games and is based on the story in the book "Dave Dawson with the Pacific Fleet"

Dave Dawson was the lead character in a number of books, called "The War Adventure Series" written by Robert Sidney Brown from 1942 - 1946. A couple of those books were converted to board games. This is one of those games and is based on the story in the book "Dave Dawson with the Commandos"
Only game published by Design Origin, done in 1984 and of course based on the game of Jai-Alai known as the fastest sport in the world.

Players get 6 cards and must create hamburgers with more points than opponents. Every turn they may change 1 card and must open 1 component in front of them. If all hamburgers are completed scoring takes place and player with the most points is winner.

Components:
52 cards

You are teaching witches how to fly at Blocksberger Flugschule. Only the most talented witches are admitted there.

You have to let five witches fly as high and far as possible. Every witch that succeeds will give you a spellbook. The player with the most spellbooks wins.

item.description:
The Unpredictable Game of Making Connections

Gather your sunglasses, snowshoes and mosquito spray - it’s time to travel to new destinations with the 10 Days Series - the Americas!

Players use destination and transportation tiles to chart a course through North, Central and South America and the Caribbean - touring by airplane, cruise ship or on foot. With a little luck and clever planning, you just might outmaneuver your fellow travelers and be the first to make connections for a complete ten day journey!

Gameplay
Players begin by filling their tile holders, drawing and placing tiles into 10 spaces. Each space is a day of a player's trip. Each tile shows a country, a plane, or a ship. Tiles are drawn and placed one at a time, and cannot be moved once placed. Once all players' holders are full, a face-down draw pile is made of the remaining tiles, as well as three face-up discard piles. On his or her turn, a player either takes a face-down tile from the draw pile, or a face-up tile from the top of a discard pile. He or she then decides whether to exchange the new tile with an old one. The tile not being kept is then discarded.
Players are attempting to have all 10 days of their trip connect, either by foot, by plane, or by ship. To connect by foot, countries must be adjacent or connected. To connect by plane, a plane of a certain color must be placed between two countries of the same color. To connect by ship, the ship must be placed between countries adjacent to that ocean/sea (or one ship can connect to another). The first person to build a fully connected trip wins.
Contains:
40 destination tiles
23 transportation tiles
8 tile holders
Map game board
Rules

item.description:
Game consists of a metal, two-sided board; a teeter-totter launching platform; and 6 little Tiki statue figures -- 3 blue and 3 green -- each with strong magnets in their hands and feet. The blue and green figures are of opposite polarity.

Play is simple:
1. Place tiki on launcher.
2. Place launcher close to the metal board.
3. Place finger on launcher and press.

The figure flips into the air and hopefully lands on the the board. The magnets are strong enough that generally the tiki will right itself vertically (either right-side up or upside down). You alternate colors in hopes of forming a stack of figures.

Score is based on where the figures land on the island depicted on the board and how high the stacks are.

The reverse side of the board contains a dartboard-like target.

From publisher's website:
In 1989, the governments of eastern Europe fell leading to an end of the Warsaw Pact. The Soviet leadership surrendered to the political and economic realities they faced. Events could have been different. Last Battle for Germany is a simulation of a military climax of the Cold War. The game is played against a backdrop of unknown political and military events over which the players have no control, but to which they must react. Players maneuver their divisions, brigade and regiments across a map with 15 kms per hex during turns representing 48 hour. An innovative game system represents each subordinate commander's headquarters and support assets. An integrated air game completes this definitive simulation of a Warsaw Pact-NATO conflict.

From publisher's website:
TriForce is an innovative strategy game offers wargaming in an exciting science-fiction format. Move one-inch playing pieces containing futuristic forces to capture key areas of the board. Combat is resolved with a unique dice roll system. The board features oversized hexagons with dramatic colors instead of terrain. All of the basic wargaming concepts are here in a game you can play with anyone.

Invasion of the Body Snatchers is a party game for 8-21 players based off of the popular Mafia and Werewolf games. One of the players is secretly an alien invader in a human body and is turning the citizens of Lake Terror into pod people one by one. Can the town find and lynch the alien menace before it's too late? It won't be easy, but you will have fun finding out.

item.description:
This game is played with two standard decks of cards. One of them is dealt to the players evenly (the remaining cards remain face down). Then everyone has half minute to memorize his cards. Then the cards from the other pack are revealed one at a time, and players can claim they have the matching pair among their cards.

After going through the deck every player scores 1 point for his card if he card alone claimed it, and p points if it was claimed by someone else as well, where p is the number of players.

Published by the U.S. Department of Transportation to promote the use of seat belts. Each player rolls a die and moves along a track. the first player to get the amusement park wins.

Some spaces are marked with hazards that cause the loss of a turn. Other spaces cause the player to get out the car. When movement resumes, a Safety Belt card must be drawn. If the player forgets to do this, a turn is lost. There are two exits, which if landed on, can shorten the trip.

It is a game for children who don't mind being preached to while playing.

This game is played with a part of a standard deck of cards. Depending on the number of players, some cards are removed. Then tricks are played. The uniqueness of the game is that the score depends on the number of tricks won in a strange way. For example with five players there are five tricks, and the score is 1 for winning 1 trick, 2 for 2 tricks, 5 for 0 tricks, 6 for 3 tricks, 8 for 4 tricks and 0 for 5 tricks.

More information can be found at http://www.davidparlett.co.uk/oricards/minimis.html

From the rulebook:

"Intrigue, trade and war in the Dune universe."

"Dune's universe, between the advent of Muad'Dib. Political, economic and military struggle between the Noble Houses of the Imperium. Meddle in politics during the Landsraad Council, influencing the Padishah Emperor. Acquire wealth, speculating on Semuta Drug and Pundi Rice prices in the CHOAM. Plan hostile actions against rivals, under the limitations of the Great Convention."

Components:

"The game is conducted on 3 boards: on the LANDSRAAD board you can plan political actions; on the CHOAM board you can trade resources for SOLARI (the Imperium currency); on the KANLY board you can plan assassinations, sabotage actions, or even full-scale wars."

"Tokens represent commodities (SPICE MELANGE, HAGAL QUARTZ, etc.), or SOLARI (the Imperium currency). Also, there are tokens to represent three NOBLES for each Noble House, and for their soldiers (TROOPERS, SABOTEURS and ASSASSINS). Also there are tokens to represent the special ADVISORS (Mentat or Bene Gesserit) which you could be provided if you met the Emperor's favour."

"Cards represent useful situations which could help you during your quest for power. The most powerful ones are you cannot obtain by chance: they are PETITIONS to the Padishah Emperor which he has graciously agreed to concede (or, sometimes, not to concede). Less powerful situations are just acts of FATE."

Gameplay summary:

"Each player will represent a Noble House and will be given three NOBLE tokens: he will use those tokens to attempt actions in each turn. Actions could be political (LANDSRAAD board), trade (CHOAM board) or hostile (KANLY board): to represent that a player is attempting an action, he will put one of his NOBLE in the appropriate slot on the appropriate board. The number of action a player could do in a turn will be therefore generally limited by the NOBLE tokens he has, even if it will be possible to increase it by mean of ADVISORS."

"Each turn is divided in three phases: LANDSRAAD, CHOAM and KANLY; each to be played on the appropriate board."

Victory:

"When a player will draw the End Game Fate Card, he will immediately show it, and the game will end. The Noble house with the most SOLARI will win the game."

From the rulebook:

"Ever wondered what is it like to be a Super Evil Villain Mastermind attempting to take over the world, scheming twisted plots in his Hidden Lair? Now you can be one."

"In order to win the game you have to CONQUER THE WORLD!!!! BWHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA!!!!!!!!!! At the beginning of the game, each player is dealt three Objective Cards at random, which are to be kept secret. In order to CONQUER THE WORLD!!!! you have to fulfil your three objectives."

In this tongue-in-cheek game, the players are evil super-villains operating from secret lairs scattered around the globe. The players send out their lowly Minions who perform acts of infamy around the world and attempt to recruit new Minions.

Ximaera is played on a 3x3 hexagonal board.
There are,off board,sets of three stones for four different types(a total of 12 stones).The stones of one type are called pivots.All stones are neutral and can be used by either player.
On each turn,each player must drop or move one stone.
Pivots may also jump over an adjacent stone.
A player wins by:
1.Connecting three stones of the same kind.
2.If he has no valid move.
3.Opponent repeats a board position for the third time.

item.description:
From the rulebook:

"So You Want to Become a Dungeon Keeper? Want to Create a Dark Underground Fortress and fill it with Wicked Minions? Want to Create an Evil Empire, bringing Chaos, Death and Destruction? Want to Bash pitiful, useless Heroes? Welcome to the Unofficial Dungeon Keeper Card Game."

"You've got lands (Rooms). You've got Creatures. You've got 20 LifePoints. Just like in magic. Different Rooms are needed to Summon more Creatures, or to research Spells or to build Artifacts, and in general to be more Powerful."

"But there's come the fun part. Creatures can't be anywhere: they must be In a Room. To represent this, you need to put your Creatures near the Rooms they're in. A creature in a Room can defend it, but cannot defend a different Room . . . So be wary not to expand your Dungeon too much, or you will be unable to defend it."

"A Creature in a Room can also use the Room. So, for example, your Warlock in your Library will be able to research a Spell (or to defend the Library). If you want him to defend the Lair, instead, you can move him in the Lair (in the appropriate Turn Phase), but then he will be unable to research a Spell (as he need to be in the Library to do so)."

"You can win in two ways: 1) Kill the Avatar when he's attacking your Dungeon (The World Will Be Mine! Victory), 2) Kill the other Dark Lord (BWHAHA ! Victory)."

name.value: Speculation: The Dynamic Real Estate Auction Game

item.description:
Speculation is an auction and strategy game for 2-6 players, built around property acquisition in a metropolitan area. The object of the game is to amass the greatest wealth through property ownership. Players first compete in an auction to purchase options on the various properties. An option gives a player the right to purchase a property, if they can mameuver the token around the board to their property. Since all players maneuver the same token, each player can try to prevent the other players from exercising their options. A player receives from the bank when he moves the token over one of their own properties, and receives from the other players when they move the token over one of his properties. At the end of the game, the player with the greatest amount of money plus property value is declared the winner.

The game ends when the last option is exercised. Any player may exercise the last option, regardless of who holds the option.

Taboo variant with cards of different difficulty level (marked in different colors) which yield 1-4 points. Also, each team gets an individual difficulty level, determined by the number of taboo words. The cards are put into a box in which a number of openings can be cleared to display the taboo words (1-4). Thus, the game can be played by adults and kids together (giving the kids less taboo words to worry about). Game ends when a team has reached a premeditated number of points.

American Gladiators - The Wall is a dexterity game based on the American Gladiators television series. It was produced by Taco Bell and given away in its kids meals.
Players take turns flicking gladiator discs at a wall trying to knock off contestants.

Japanese name roughly corresponds to "Sky Board"; this is a version of the game "Ghosts!".

Each player controls 4 angels and 4 devils on 6x6 board, their identities hidden from the opponent.

A player can win by:

 moving an angel into a goal square from the corners of the opponent's side;
 capturing all 4 of the opponent's angels; or
 tricking the opponent into capturing all 4 of the player's devils.




Players deploy their pieces and then take turns moving one to an adjacent square. They may capture enemy pieces but do not know whether it is an angel or devil until after the capture.

Dartslive Co Ltd produce 3 versions of the board game in different materials, as well as a mobile phone version.

The basic concept of this game is similar to Monopoly: Roll and move, buy fields and build extensions, pay if you step on other people's land. The dice mechanism is different, though: The fields are not lined up in a row, but all over the board, and the die rolls (one color die, one number die) determine the direction and distance in which a player moves.
There are several variants to this game, which include trivia aspects, a timed variant, etc.

name.value: Le roi Casimir et ses animaux

item.description:
Game for the very young that comes with rules variants for 1-3 year olds (!). 
In the simplest form, a kind of nursery rhyme is read out and the kids can sort the animals in the same order they appear in the rhyme.
In another game, the players roll a die and move the animal they rolled to the end of the line behind the queen. The goal is to complete the row of all eight animals.

The game consists of cards for 193 countries plus 7 special cards. The country cards contain pictures of the flags, the flags of the neighboring countries and some other information. There are various games which can be played with this material; most notably trick-taking games in which the players can form "alliances" by playing cards of neighboring countries together, which makes the cards stronger.

Jogo Mulan is a roll-and-move race-to-the-finish board game based on the cartoon, Mulan. The board depicts fifty-seven spaces that players have to move through to get to the finish. If players land on specially-coloured spaces, they refer to the instruction sheet (which comes in both Portuguese and Spanish) to see what happens to them (e.g. miss a turn, move to another space).

The game was published by Trisan Editores, a Portuguese entertainment media company.

This is a simple bowling game from the William Bruce Company. It features wooden dice that either have a blank face or a pin on them. You roll the dice and see what you have for pins remaining and then shoot for your spare. This game has similarities to other bowling type games from different companies and different publishing years. Games like Spare Time Bowling, Bowling Dice, Bowl and Score, or Bowl - A - Strike are similar types games and their may be others already in the DB.

Kunskapsjakten is a trimmed-down reimplementation of NE-spelet with 4,000 new questions compared to 8,000 in the original game. As before, players move around the board and answer questions to assemble trophies (a miniature encyclopaedia) representing ten fields of knowledge.

"Kunskapsjakten" is also the name of a single book of 1,000 additional questions, a series of books each containing 500 questions, and an online feature where you can score points by answering timed questions (Swedish only).

The game is the second game published by the shop Stategia e Tattica, the first having been "Il Sole di Austerlinz" (Austelinz's Sun), and, as the first one, was published in congiunction with a event.

The game system, as the "Il Sole di Austerlinz", takes inspiration from the "Napoleon's last Battles" one, and has about the same size of the hex while each unit can be considered equivalent to a regimental size.

A 2 player or solitaire card game based on BASKETBALL. Scrimmage your friends and pick the right combination of players. Get your team all playing the same offense and defense for maximum points scored!

Start your game with a "Jump Ball" and keep your players from fouling out so they can shoot "Free Throws", "Jump Shots", and especially "3 Pointers".

With characters from the Mid-Michigan Central Montcalm Lady Hornets Baketball team. 45 card deck included. A quick and easy to learn card game made for basketball players by a coach. This game is played at school and on bus trips by high school basketball teams.

Players decide on a grand story about who they are and may improve their story by utilizing their story telling skills and over-acting the character they are trying to portray.
As you tell your story, you will be challenged by other players to work some of their "TOPIC TILES or TOPIC CARDS" (depending on the version you have) in to your current story. If you are able to, you will make money (chips), but if not, you will lose coins. Your goal is to make it as hard as possible for the other players to work your topics in to their story by giving them the most challenging topics. Players are guided by their TOPIC cards which they find easy to explain and use for themselves, or tough to imagine an explanation, so they challenge another player which can help you earn extra money or lose it to great story tellers. Some cards contain blanks which you get to fill in to make your topics as challenging as possible.

The quickest minds & most boastful of your group will certainly have an advantage!

The game is concluded when all players vote with their coins and decide who the best story teller was. A great game or activity for acting classes, drama clubs, scouting or camping activities or other educational purposes.

The game is intended to teach children about life during World War II in the United Kingdom. Players move around the board and read facts on the squares. There are three types of interactive squares: "News Bulletin," "Read all about it," and "Quick on the Draw." The first two give facts and instruct the player to move forward or back, while the "Quick on the Draw" square gives the player a chance to interact with other players and show off their drawing skills in return for a reward of moving forward in the game.

The game contains
 1 main board
 81 black cardboard pieces (digits from 1 to 9)
 4 sets of 81 cardboard pieces (each set in different
 colour red, green, yellow and blue)
 1 booklet with tasks
 1 hourglass
 1 instruction

Payers choose the task they are going to solve from the task booklet. They place black cardboard pieces according to the model from the booklet. Next each player chooses the colour of the cardboards pieces he is going to use on the board.

The oldest player starts the game. then other player follow clockwise. The player whose turn this is places the cardboard piece he is holding in his hand on an empty square. He/she must apply to the SUDOKU rule that inat inside each row, each column and each block a digit may appear only once. When the first player made his/her move, the next player places his/her cardboard piece on the board - of course, remembering about sudoku rule. The hourglass limits the length of turn. If the hourglass becomes empty and the player has not placed his/her cardboard piece yet, he/she misses his/her chance and it is the next [;ayer's turn.

The game stops when no player can place a cardboard piece on the board.
then the players check the position of the cardboard pieces on the board in the answer booklet. If on the board there is misplaced cardboard piece, we put them aside and each player counts his/her cardboard pieces that are on the board. The winner is the person who scores the biggest number of points.

item.description:
Chess for 4 is the second game in Gpip Design's 'for 4' series of games.

Two rows of 8 fields are added on each side of a standard 8x8 chess board. 3 or 4 players can play; each player starts at a different side of the board. Standard chess rules apply, except that a piece that threatens a king cannot be captured. One king cannot be placed in check by two or more opponents at once.

The game ends when only one king remains on the board; that player is the winner.

Chess for 4 can also be played as a 2 vs 2 partnership game. In this case, you cannot capture your partner's pieces.

Sanluri, Sardinia, June 30th, 1409. Battle of Sanluri.
After centuries of struggle for the control of the island the two armies of William III of Narbonne, Judge of Arborea, and Martin the Younger, king of Sicily and Sardinia, face each other for what will arguably be the decisive battle for the destiny of Sardinia.

This game on the Battle of Sanluri uses is the same as that of Guelphs and Ghibellines published by Europa Simulazioni.

In the game, each player takes the role of the Commander-in-chief of one of the two armies. Each army consists of various battaglie, with each battaglia' composed of various units. The players are given the task of choosing and issuing specific orders for their battaglie. The game system emphasizes the progressive deterioration of the battaglie efficiency during the battle and tries to simulate the entropy on the field of battle and its effects on the chain of command and the "victory perception". The game includes rules for historical, alternative or "free" scenarios.

name.value: The Game of Great Detectives: Sherlock Holmes

item.description:
In The Game of Great Detectives, you play Sherlock Holmes against others in an adventure of skill and detection. Use your powers of detection to thwart your rival and disprove his theory of the crime before he has a chance to do the same to you. Win by completing your investigation and being the first to implicate the suspect and his motive in a crime.

WARNING
Spoiler Alert: The content of these cards contains information about the secret solutions to many Sherlock Holmes adventures.

item.description:
In this game the players guess on erotic related questions. There are three different types of questions.

1: From Me To You
questions like: "Do I think marriage is a reasonable way of living?" or "Do you think I need jealousy to be really in love?"

2: To Everybody
questions like: "Which one of us would get so jealous to smash a valuable vase against the wall?" or "Which one of us has probably had the longest love night?"

3: Who Knows It
mutiple choice questions like: "Since when does the phrase sex-appeal exist?" or "the longest kiss has been recorded in 1972. How long did it last?"

The players receive points for correct answers. The player with the most points after 15 rounds wins the game.

Each player has a base card with numbers.
The players draw cards from a stack that show multiplication or division operations.
The player who has drawn the card has to check if one of his numbers match the result of the operation. If so he places the card on the number, if not he has to put it back under the stack.
The player to complete his basecard first wins the game.

Fehlerteufel is a game that helps learning to spell.
It contains 8 packs of cards of different themes such as "what children play with", " my body" or "my garden". Each time you choose one pack to play with.
In each pack there are cards with words, pictures, letters and/or syllables. The goal for the children is to find two or three matching cards either from another players hand or from drawing a card.

In push&move D20, a free print and play board game for 2 - 6 players, each player has a set of five 20-sided dice with which he or she tries to push at least 3 opponent dice over the edge of the playing field or onto one of the dreaded "Death-Hexes" in order to win. The game is played on a hexagonal playing field which is built randomly out of a variety of different hexes with various special effects.

You take on a role of a "Muník" (there is no direct translation of the word, assume something like a Mole) and strive to dig out passages underground, finding treasures and resources, with which you can later buy pieces of a very large and Super-Heavy Digging Machine, with which you can outpower all other opposition.

The board is prepared out of many face-down tiles, which may or may not contain something worth taking. Then the players move in their turns, according to the Attributes of their Moles and the equipment they possess in search for more resources. They can store them in their Storage space and also sell them for gold and vice versa.

Ultimately they want to buy and build the parts of the Digging Machine and the first one that succeeds, is the winner.

The game consists of cards numbered 1-9. One one side of the number, there is also a red line. The goal is to complete rows of 15 or put equal numbers or ascending numbers next to each other. All these actions score points. The red lines next to one side of each number interrupt rows.

Roll and move game first published in "Le Figaro" dated 30 MAR 1889. This is a satirical game based on the career of General Ernest Boulanger who was a reactionary politician seen to be a potential military dictator in France. He was the Minister of War and while in office committed suicide.

A battling top game originating from Japan by Takara, was brought to the US by Hasbro. Accompanied by a Manga and TV show, Beyblades are customizable battling tops, with different arenas available for play and many different parts available to customize tops, from Jumping Bases to Grind attack rings.

item.description: A Simple game in which two players must capture each other’s pieces by forming different shapes, the game is played on a “board” consisting of two triangular segments, it is the goal of the player to control more of each triangular segment than his/her opponent by capturing his/her pieces.

The Pool Game is an promotional game made by the Fox Pool company. The goal of the game is to build an in-ground swimming pool at one of four houses. The mechanics are an extremely basic roll-and-move, with the only variety granted by Pool Cards, which mostly just cause the player to lose or gain a turn. Some of the topics covered are extremely technical, such as spaces that read things like "Set network of reinforcing rods on backfill rods. Support deck, not backfill soil."

name.value: The Gentlemen of the South Sandwiche Islands

item.description:
Jules and Hodge are competing for the attentions of the Lady Ashley. Each wants to speak with her alone. They must do this by crossing bridges to leave the others behind.

There are 6 pieces on the board. You control a master piece and a servant piece. On your turn you can move one, or the other, across a bridge and decide who follows. (The bridges only permit a certain number across.) Some players try to lead her away from the group, and others use their servant to lead others away. The game is very easy to learn. At any time a player only has several choices... but be careful, there are more than 300,000 different possible arrangements for the 6 pieces on the board.

item.description:
Moai, originally known as NiMeMo, is an abstract strategy game. Each player has nine pieces, and at the start of play all the pieces are spread about on the board. This board consists of eight sliding boards, each divided into nine fields.

Through a combination of sliding the boards and moving the pieces, you must gather all of your pieces on one of the nine field boards before any other player does.

Each Player gets a board with numbers 1 to 6 in 6 different colours. (All six cards that come with the game are different, that is, all 36 combinations of number and colour appear exactly once.) Additionally there's the bank in the middle.

First, all players put the same amount of money into the bank. The players then alternately roll one number and one colour die to determine one field (combination of number and colour). The player who has that field on his card takes the rolled number of chips from the bank. (If the card is not used, the person who rolled the die has to pay that amount instead.)

It's mostly a casino game, and a great source for game material for other games.

This game is mostly about knowledge about animals. There are animal cards with a photo on the front side and the answers to 6 questions ("What's the name?", "Where does it live?", "What does it eat?", ...) on the back. (The questions are the same for all cards.)

Additionally, the game contains one board per continent, with 12 numbered fields. Accordingly, there are 12 animal cards per continent in the game.

The game comes with several game variants that are similar to other quiz games. Most of the variants given in the official rules however are neither very playable nor very balanced. At least the game comes with plenty of material for making up your own rules.

Based on the TV documentation series of the same name with Prof.Dr.Dr.h.c. Bernhard Grzimek.

In this pure roll-and-move game, each player is a hunter. Each hunter moves along his own path. When reaching an animal field exactly, the animal is shot and the player gains points. There are some positions on the board where a player can shoot another player's animal.

The player with most points in the end wins.

It's the scandal of the year - Mr X has been found dead in his office and the prime suspects have plenty to hide. Whether you're the murderer covering your trail or the dectectives searching for the truth, you'll love this game with all its twists, turns and mysteries.

Detectives move around the outside of the board, collecting evidence and asking questions to build their case, whilst the murderer tries to halt their progress.

Speed is of the essence for the murderer as they try to make 5 laps of the inside loop and escape before a detective can build their case.

Game Board
6 Playing pieces
20 Murderer Identity Cards
45 Physical Appearance cards
50 Confession Word cards
25 Murderer Chance cards
25 Detective Chance cards
"Yes" Card
"No" Card
"Don't Know" card
Suspect profile sheet
confession keywords sheet
Wrong Turn card
Tainted Evidence card
5 Getaway Mile Tokens
Pads, pencils and a die

Pitchnut is a tabletop dexterity game of French Canadian origins that borrows elements from Carrom, Crokinole and Pichenotte. American game players will recognize elements of pool and shuffleboard. The game is played on a handmade wooden board 28 square inches with pockets in each corner. There are Canadian and American rules variations, but all games involve flicking wooden disk "shooters" into lighter wooden disks such that the lighter disks land in one of the four pockets.

Educational game that teaches about letters. To each vowel (A,E,I,O,U only, although it is a German game) a wooden animal is assigned; the consonants have animal cards. 
Four game concepts are included, which require the kids to recognize and/or sort the letters. Some require a story to be read by an adult. The kids can sort the letters as they appear in the story, name them, remember them, etc.

From the Box:

The Beadazzling Card Game
For 2-6 players, Aged 6 and up
5 shapes, 4 colors, 3 patterns. Match 2 of the 3 to make a beadlightful string of Beadcards. You'll be beadsotted with them all!

6 Different Easy-To-Learn Card Games!
Beadecked - Build an unbeadlievably beadutiful Beadcard necklace.
Beadspoke - Tailor-make your own string or Beadwitch another Beader by beading on theirs.
Beadtween - From beadginning to end, taking beads is the trick. But don't wait, you might bead late!
Beadmarket - In this Go Fish! twist, if another Beader won't beadstow a match, the Beadmarket may.
Beadominoes - Create one beadazzling string in this Dominoes modbeadification.
Beadrummy - Form combeadnations of 3 and 4 Beadcards in this beadguiling spin on Rummy.

item.description:
"Laterali" is a mental game for 3 - 12 players, challenging their lateral thinking skills.

The first player is reading the topic of a Laterali card and is betting a number of requested answers, which all other players together are not able to find. The more answers the player is asking for (the more difficult it is for the others) the less improvement he can make on the board - the easier he is challenging the others, the further he can move forward on the board, when the team can't reach the demanded number of answers.
All other players (the team) are now challenged to find as many possible answers within 1 minute and try to fulfill his presettings. If they can do so, the team has won this round and each team member can move forward and also has the chance to "beat" the questioner and send him back home.

It is the next players turn to pull a Laterali card and challenging the others by betting a requested number of answers...
As soon a player has reached the finish line he has won the game.

The questions are very difficult, although there are always many answers possible - it is not a trivial quiz game "one question - one answer" and matching answers can only be found by extraordinary methods of resulution. Therefor Laterali can be used as training-tool for lateral thinking methods.

Laterali is available in 2 different game versions, Laterali Light with 432 question-cards or Laterali DeLuxe with 648 Laterali-cards. Both versions include a game board and 12 3D-figurines and a timer.

Laterali is available in German and will be presented at the Nuernberg Toy Fair 2010 the first time.
For 2011/2012 an English Version will be available.

ROBOSOCCER is a board game of movement and ball control whose objective is to score a goal (taking your ball to the last row) before your opponent does. Move your robots, and push, and jump above your opponent's robots until you score a goal.

Re-implements: Mundialito (Gold Cup)

item.description: Finland was part of Swedish kingdom for many centuries and in the 13th century the building of a road from the Finnish capital of the day Turku to the secondary city of Viipuri on the Russian border was started. The road was called Kuninkaantie (King's Road). In the game Kuninkaantie players visit 27 notable towns and villages along this particular road. If you'll happen stop in any of these locations, there will be tasks for you to accomplish, for example laughing at the king's rage. The main goal of the game is to learn local history and it's offered for schools as a tool for teaching.

Game features a football field gameboard where you would keep track of the ball possession and a number of spinners (8) that were used to get the results of the play. Circa 1940 Game comes with 6 gameboards each measuring 9/5" X 11" that are titled: Housewares, Bakery & Candies, Market, Drygoods & Notions, Toy Shop and Drug Store, 149 Small Square Counters representing this that you can buy and sell (costs range from 5 cents to 25 cents) and some play coins.

Einspruch (Objection) is a trivia game about (German) law. Players draw cards with statements regarding laws and try to guess whether the statements are true or false. Players have chips valued from 1 to 3 that they can bet on the result depending on how certain they are. Those who guessed correctly can move their pawns according to the chip they bet. The first player to reach the goal wins.

Take turns to play number and action cards to change the play pile's total. Get the pile to 21 without going bust to get one of your pawn cards home. But watch out - someone could play a SORRY! card and steal your win.

Portable, playable, speedy SORRY! fun for the whole family

item.description:
Israeli Whist is a trick taking standard deck playing card game. In Israel, the game is simply called Whist but differs from classical Whist in significant ways. There are no partnerships, trump is determined by a Bridge-like auction rather than last card dealt, and each player makes an Oh Hell!-like forecast of number of tricks to take.

Each hand of Israeli Whist includes an auction round to determine trump, a bidding round to specify number of tricks to take, and finally a card play round to determine who made their bid.

Players who missed their bid, score -10 points for each trick over or under their bid. Players who made their bid exactly, score 10 points plus a bonus of the number of tricks taken squared. See variants for non-exponential scoring systems to reduce the likelihood of a runaway leader.

One appeal of Israeli Whist is that the ability to judge a hand's strength is more important than relying on luck to get a good hand. For example, consistently making your bid outweighs consistently winning the auction to name trump.

Although the standard game is for exactly four players, see the variant section for ways to accommodate 3-7 players.

This is a 4-player partnership version of the game Duck Soup. It is played with two deck of standard cards. Each player is dealt 13 cards.

There are two phases (caleed Duck course and, after thirteen tricks, Soup course) with different trick-taking rules. The trick is taken by the exact duplicate of the card played, or failing that the last-played card of the same rank as the one led, or, failing that: the lowest card of the suit led in the first half of the game (Duck), or the highest in the second half (Soup). Another difference is that Aces are low during the Duck course and high during the Soup course.

The final score of a partnership is the number of cards won by a player multiplied by the number of card won by his partner.

This game is played with a standard deck of cards. Each player is dealt 13 cards and then tricks are played.

If a trick does not contain a match (two or more cards of the same rank or suit, or three or more cards in numerical order), it is taken by the highest card played, and its penalty score is that of the lowest card played.

If the trick does contain a match, it is won by the last player to duplicate a rank or suit, or to complete a run of three or four. Its penalty score is a multiple of 10 as follows:10 for two of the same suit, 20 for two of the same rank (pair), 30 for a match of three cards and 40 for a match of four cards.

The overall winner is the player with the lowest penalty score at the end of eight deals, or when one player has reached 250 in penalties.

This game is played with thirty cards from a standard deck of cards. Both player is dealt 15 cards, hence they exactly know the cards in the hand of the other player, this is the novelty in this otherwise simple trick-taking game. Then the dealer determines the target parity, tricks are played, and bonus points are awarded for winning the required parity of things. A three-player variant also exists, but it lacks the element of perfect information.

This horse racing game comes from McLoughlin Bros. You are required to roll your dice and avoid and/or overcome the hazzards of a steeple chase race. Of course, first person across the finish line wins.

"Put your wildlife knowledge to the test!"

Players move plastic explorers around a colorful map featuring jungle, desert, and mountain terrain as they answer questions about wildlife. The categories on the question cards include Environment, Predator, and Animal Challenge. There are two levels of play for children and adults.

Includes the board, six high quality explorer figures, three sets of question cards, six sturdy score cards with punch-out animal tokens, a die, and a plastic storage insert. The rules are printed inside the box.

(from the box)

The Crazy Game Of Balance And Skill

Are you level headed enough?

Roll the dice and prepare for hysterics as players attempt to balance blocks on their heads. An action packed game for all the family!

(How to play)

Each player puts on a "hat." Players roll a special die, and one or all of the players place foam blocks on their head. The winner is the last to keep all of the blocks on their head!

Le Grand Chef is a roll and move trivia game that tests knowledge of French cusine and its related history. The game's wooden box contains eight different types of question decks, a board map of France, pawns and dice.

name.value: On the Road to California Wines

item.description: On the Road to California Wines is billed as a "marketing tool for the wine trade". The wooden box contains a roll-and-move trivia game featuring the regions, notable vineyards, and wines of California.

[Executive Order 134340: Full-scale retreat from the combat zone, effective at 0800 tomorrow. All soldiers unable to return on army helicopters will be considered MIA and no evacuation support given past the 0800 deadline tomorrow.]


One half-mile separates you and your comrades from a one-way ticket back to the homeland. There's a problem though: you're going through a minefield. It's not so bad though, your squadron planted the mines, so everyone knows where at least the mines they placed are. Working together to plan a route through the field should get you safely across… except the helicopter has room for only one of you.

Claymore is a card-driven race game in which players are traversing a field littered with mines. Some mine locations are known and controlled by the player, but most are not. Players must utilize cards and their own observational talent in order to cross the board safely, and hope that their opponents' men detonate landmines, pushing them back.
